Review Text: It's the first dam in the Mahaweli project and the second dam from the up stream. Its visible from the main road from Ramboda. If you want to get closer, you can take the Ulapane - Pussellawa Road. There are various ways to get to this road. You can either come from Gampola or Pussellawa/ Tawalantenne side. We started all the way from Ulapane (which was a bit of a detour) since we wanted to see the Fools Bridge, which is visible from the Ulapane bridge. There is also a hanging bridge and then you get to Kotmale bridge. Google map directions are accurate and the road is in good condition. You have to pass the dam which is on the right side of the road, towards Pussellawa side for about 500 meters. Then you come to an observation point. You need to get a ticket which allows you access to a look out point and a tiny museum. Then you can take the same ticket and go back to the dam which will allow you to walk the length of the dam. As soon as you pass the observation deck and go towards Pussellawa, you get a left turn to Mahaweli Maha Seya. On the way to Mahaweli maha seya you also get a right turn to see "Dehadu Kadulla". This is supposed to be an entrance gate in the border between Ruhuna and Malaya and the very gate used by Prince Gemunu around 2000 years ago!. It seems to be in perfectly good condition. So I am not sure whether this is the real thing or a replica based on folk lore. Once you pass the Kotmale dam and go towards Pussellawa in the Ulapane Pussallewa road, you get to Ranamune Raja pihilla, another landmark in prince Gamunu's story. This is a beautiful paddy field with "out of this world" views and a famed fountain. A little while after, this road meets the Talawakele - Tawalanetenne road. It's best to take that route to get to A5 as the Pussellawa Road in not in good conditon thereafter. Also, while the roads were in perfect conditon, there were not many places to have lunch after Gampola. When we visited the previous time, we went to the Kotmale rest house which was a left turn-off before coming to the dam. There was also a home stay kind of place, right next to Ranamune pihilla, but we couldn't figure out whether they served lunch or not. If you know prince gemunu's story or if you have followed "Ganga Dinge" this would be a perfect road trip. Even if that is not the case, this trip does offer lovely views and an added bonus is that it is a rarely travelled road, so you can enjoy its beauty in all its pristine glory .
Beautiful view. once you buy a ticket you can use the same to watch the reservoir and dam from observation point as well walk on the dam. Further you can see the kotmale dam museum.
The road through the Dam closes at 6pm. The authorities doesn't entertain tourists hanging around and taking pictures but the walk is well worth it.
Cool and interesting. Especially if you’re staying in the villa which was owned by the minister who had initiated it...

Fortunate to visit the viewing gallery with family to witness first hand experience. Direct and closer view of the dam and surrounding offer great photo shoot opportunity. School children can learn the history of the dam, including output, processes and the construction milestones.

Recommend doing the trek in good daylight. The climb down to the Dam is steep and you need good footwear. Once you get to the Dam the views are breathtaking. You really get to take in nature at its best and  mountain fresh air. You can get a Tuk tuk both ways for LKR 1000 from the entrance to the Pedro Estate Lover’s Leap division.
Good place to relax and meditate .awesome quiet and hear natures sounds only .stunning scenery and lovely foliage ..a painters dream location .

Kotmale Dam is a really beautiful and memorable place. View of Kotmale Reservoir from the dam is breathtaking. The mountain range behind, adds much more to its beauty. Unlike most of other dams in Sri Lanka, Kotmale Dam is a linear dam, with a length of 600m. Just make sure, you walk along the dam to the other end, to feel the beauty in full. And don't forget to observe Kotmale Mahaweli Maha Seya seen little far from the dam. Kotmale Power Station is the second largest power station is Sri Lanka.
If you get sunny day, better. First you need to get tickets from visiting center, 30 Rupee per head. After you can come to dam Where you can walk. Vehicle allow only for resident
Set in the beautiful valley of Kotmale, the view is amazing and is a must visit. You can either view the dam from the viewpoint or walk along the dam with a ticket.
you will see a unique and beautiful view. do not forgot take a picture of this place. if you wish you can walk trough the dam but have to get permission from authority.

The walk along the bridge was very exciting especially when all the school children joined us.  the views are wonderful and there is a little museum which explains the historical value of the dam  to Kotmale province.

The Kotmale Dam view point is just a place to have the most gorgeous views of the dams, the lake and the surrounding waterfalls. It is just mesmerizing. Enjoy the games of the clouds over the lakes and the hills. The breathtaking views of the nature gives mind a fresh start. We will cherish the views for a long time.

Its a great place to visit if you are in Sri Lanka and up country. There is lots of history involved which you will love to see and hear. Worth a visit. Make sure you plan other places to visit also if you travel upto Kotmale.

This damn is in a very pretty place in the country. The area still has a lot of old Sri Lankan charm. I used to spend a lot of time during my school holidays when I was growing up in Sri Lanka. This area is a bit away from the normal tourist trail. Could easily spend discovering the area.
You can visit this impressive damm. If you are there please stay in Mas Villa along the lake and love the view, the food and the marvelous staf.

We visited the dam as part of a trip with a tuktuk in the area. First stop is at the museum at the dam viewpoint, where they charge the entry fee. The view from there was indeed very nice, providing the opportunity for some great photos of the dam and the lake. The museum itself had a few interesting pictures of the construction, but didn't contain too many other interesting things. Next up is that you can walk over the dam, which also provides a good opportunity for some impressive photos. Unfortunately, it is not possible to view any actual rooms or machines of the dam or the power plant. But nevertheless, it's worth to visit the dam and to spend around 30 min - 1h there.

Well worth a visit if you are driving by! The view point area has a small museum with photographs of the construction, a miniature layout of the hydro dam and info about the project. Surprisingly, the construction was completed way earlier than the expected date, so that opening was moving forward by a few months! You can also access the dam itself, which is about 1 km away from the view point. Vehicles were not allowed when we visited in Nov 2016, but it was accessible by foot; very picturesque location! Also, do visit the Kotmale Seya (stupa) / Mahaweli maha stupa which is overlooking the dam. Its close by and well worth a visit!

Kotmale dam and reservior are the most popular tourist attractions of the area. There is museum and view point at Kotmale Reservior. You can have a fantastic view towards the reservior from this view point. The Dam also can be visited but entry point is about 1km down the view point. Mahaweli Maha Saya is the pagoda built to commemerat all temples submerged during Kotmale project. It is one of the tallest Stupas in Sri Lanka. Other tourist attractions around the area are Dehadu Kadulla (ancient gate of Kotmale), Ranamune Pihilla (water spring used by prince Gemunu for bath), Morape Dewalaya, Pusulpitiya RMW and Ulapane False Bridge.

Kotmale project is one of five major headworks projects under the Mahaweli Ganga scheme. The dam site is at Kadadora located about 6.6 km upstream of the confluence of Kotmale Oya. It is close to the Pussellawa-Ulapane road and is nearly 37 KM from Kandy town and average of 135 KM from Colombo. The nearest rail-head is Ulapane, 11 KM away. You might get the permission for access the site and there is a view point for your study purposes.  All the details about the dam project is available for you. Ideal for student, photographers and travelers.  In keeping with ancient irrigation tradition of Lankan, a modern large stupa named as Mahaweli Maha Seya is dwelling at visibly to the Kotmale dam. Love #nature #photography #driving #travel @shashikasign Pics taken on 20151003 Camera: Lumia 640XL

The dam was very beautiful with a view present in Centre of big rocks.. It was likely long from the top view.. And the entrance ticket was around 20 LKR.. There are models and photographs were displayed at the time of built. The dam generates power and it was constructed underground. People allowed through vehicles on the road it must be an nice closer view since we visited late in the evening we were not allowed. On the way out there are local fruit vendors with fresh fruits were u can buy mainly butter fruit and seasonal fruit..

Purchase the ticket before arriving to view the dam as it is located 500 above the dam.Project Model is there in the ticketing premises.No vehicles allowed inside the entrance except nearby village residents.Evening along the dam could be very attractive

Kotmale Dam is one of the few places to visit if you are in the area. Especially in the evening it is very serene with a great view on both sides, the valley and the lake. But more than the dam itself, drive further up to a well known route that takes you down to the surface of the lake. Here you find a semi sumberged temple which is apparently under water during Monsoon, and only appears during periods of draught. This story by itself was mystifying. There was no information about the temple in the site itself, almost like a less known gem. Devotees had to get into the water to face towards temple and pray. It was quite a sight, almost like seeing something ancient, historical and so mysterious.

Kotmale reservoir is a part of "Mahaweli Development Project" and built during 1979 to 1985. There are two roads, one from "Tawalamtenne" and other from "Gampola". Road is not bad, but it's a mountain road. There is a view point and we had to take tickets from there. Tickets valid for access both view point and the dam. Don't forget to view the small museum near the view point. "Mahaweli Maha Seya" a pagoda built after the completion of Mahaweli Development Project also nearby. Located in top of a mountain. Don't drive there unless you are driving a 4x4 and you are a skilled driver. They allowed to photograph the place.So you can take lot's of nice pictures.

Kothmale Dam is one of the most fantastic place that took my mind. It is  really an amazing experience. A huge project!! Cool,refreshing surrounding. I think that We as the new generation young people should try to  do such memorable and useful things for our country's next generation. Our Grand parents  sacrificed their houses, lands for this major project. And also their dedication is marvelous. There's a museum too. As a student i recommend this place for educational purposes.
The dam was jus so so lika any other dam. Just located near the forreat that makes it more beautiful and more interesting.

Only a few know that Kotmale is a historical city related to ancient kingdoms.  The newly built reservoir in late 70's adds glamor to this wonderful valley consists of ancient temples, waterfalls,  ttraditional industries and charming people. This dam is located at an alternative road to Nuwaraeliya (Little England). I encourage everyone to enjoy this peaceful environment by spending 2-3 hours in the vicinity.  My only worry is that there is a preferential treatment to visitors known to the management and the security. So others will have restrictions to enjoy the beauty.

The Kotmale project is one of the five major projects undertaken under the Accelerated Mahaweli River scheme. The project was completed in 1985. It is not to be mistaken for the more recent Upper Kotmale Hydropower Project in Talawakale. The dam can be visited by paying a nominal fee and you can walk right across it. The reservoir and the surrounding mountains make up a peaceful view. There is also a tiny museum. The Mahaweli Mahaseya is visible from the dam. It is a gigantic gleaming 100 ft dome which houses a smaller stupa within it. The acoustics inside is amazing.  Its construction commenced in 1983 but still remains incomplete. 18 temples and 2 Hindu Kovils were inundated in order to build the Kotmale Reservoir. The late Gamini Dissanayake made the Stupa to compensate for the loss of these religious shrines. Some temples are visible when the water level is low. There is a lot of folklore attached to Kothmale including stories about Prince Dutugamunu.
